I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will improve the capacity of selected 
developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  applying 
differentiated approaches in context-sensitive situations.1 Context-sensitive situation is a broader 
definition  of  fragile  and  conflict-affected  situations  (FCAS)  that  also  encompasses  defined 
geographical areas in upper-middle-income countries with population segments that experience 
persistent poverty caused by fragility and conflict. 
 
2.  Context-sensitive situations are intended to go beyond FCAS classification2 (i) to consider 
the distinct challenges that DMCs may face in achieving development objectives in defined 
geographical areas;  and (ii) to improve the effectiveness of ADB assistance in those areas, in 
line with ADB’s Strategy 2030 goal to promote inclusiveness in lagging areas and pockets 
of poverty, and the related seven Operational Plans.3  
 
3.  The TA will (i) review and update ADB’s 2013 FCAS operational plan,4 (ii) operationalize 
differentiated approaches to context-sensitive situations, and (iii) support trainings and innovative 
knowledge-based approaches. Through these components, ADB will help DMCs progress along 
the fragility-to-stability continuum.5  
 
4.  The  TA  concept  was  endorsed  during  the  corporate  priority  framework  meeting  in 
November 2019 and is included in the 2020 ADB Management-approved results-based work plan 
of the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC).6 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
5.  Strategy 2030 recognizes that fragile and conflict-affected countries “face a high degree 
of  fragility  and  a  considerable  need  for  institutional  strengthening,”  and  advocates  for  a 
differentiated  approach  to  how  ADB  operates  in  such  situations. 7  FCAS  countries  are 
characterized by political instability; weak governance and institutional capacity; economic and 
social insecurity; greater vulnerability to the effects of climate change; and, in the case of small 
island  developing  states  (SIDS),  remoteness  and  isolation.  The  broader  context-sensitive

Manila. 
2  Countries are classified FCAS using a harmonized approach agreed with the World Bank, the African Development 
Bank and ADB. In the Asia and the Pacific region, the harmonized approach uses an average of ADB’s country 
performance assessment and the World Bank’s country policy and institutional assessment. Countries rated below 
3.2 on a scale of 0–6, or those with a United National or regional peacekeeping or peace building mission in the 
previous 3 years, are classified FCAS. For 2019, the following ADB member countries were classified FCAS: 
Afghanistan and Myanmar were conflict-affected; and the following Pacific small islands developing states (the 
Federated States of Micronesia, Kiribati, the Marshall Islands, Nauru, Papua New Guinea, Timor-Leste, Solomon 
Islands, and Tuvalu) were classified fragile. ADB monitors Vanuatu as it is close to the fragile classification cutoff of

approach will address the specificities and underlying causes of vulnerability of DMCs in defined 
geographical areas—beyond those countries classified as FCAS (footnote 2)—and will help ADB 
improve its operational effectiveness in those areas. 
 
6.  ADB’s differentiated approach to FCAS recognizes that fragility and conflict are complex 
and  multifaceted.8 Countries  experiencing  context-sensitive  situations  confront  obstacles  to 
development that other DMCs may not face or may be better positioned to overcome. To 
successfully operate in these situations, ADB follows international best practices based on (i) 
ensuring  context  sensitivity,  (ii)  doing  no  harm,  (iii)  increasing  capacity  assistance  and 
development, (iv) enhancing monitoring for continuous improvement, and (v) seeking progress 
on the fragility-to-stability continuum.  
7.  ADB has put considerable effort in supporting fragile and country affected countries since 
2007, when the differentiated approach for weakly-performing countries (later identified as FCAS) 
was adopted. Then, in 2013, the FCAS Operational Plan (footnote 4) was approved and continues 
currently to guide ADB operations in FCAS. Much of ADB’s FCAS operations and experience is 
in the Pacific region, as eight SIDS in the Pacific are classified as FCAS. ADB’s operations 
departments, including the Private Sector Operations Department, and resident missions are 
charged with the implementation of the differentiated approaches. 
8.  Two corporate evaluation reports have provided insights and recommendations on ADB’s 
operations  in  FCAS.9 These  evaluations  noted  that  common  factors  are  affecting  project 
performances  in  FCAS  countries,  namely,  inadequate  understanding  of  the  underlying 
development problem; limited or overestimation of institutional capacity to achieve project outputs 
and outcomes; and poor government coordination, which places a substantial burden on national 
institutions. The reports also emphasized the need to increase project implementation capacity. 
9.  ADB assistance to FCAS DMCs has increased over the years. The FCAS portfolio grew 
from $4.5 billion in 2015 to $6.9 billion in 2019, to represent 7% of ADB’s sovereign portfolio. ADB 
increased its overall allocations to FCAS DMCs in the Asian Development Fund (ADF) 12th 
replenishment  by  more  than  40%  compared  to  ADF  11. 10  Yet,  despite  some  positive 
performances, success rates of projects in FCAS countries have recently declined. Only 54% of 
the  sovereign  operations  completed  in  FCAS  countries  were  rated  successful  in  2019. 11 
Performances in FCAS DMCs dropped by 19 percentage points in 2017–2019 after an all-time 
high of 73% in 2016−2018 .12 The causes of the decline—exacerbated by national or subnational 
conflicts, or by size and remoteness in the case of SIDS—range from weak governance and 
institutions, to deficient government transparency, to knowledge and capacity gaps. Ensuring that 
the outputs and outcomes of ADB-financed operations in fragile situations are sustainable 
remains a critical challenge.  
10.  Achieving  development  and  progress  on  the  fragility-to-stability  continuum  requires 
overcoming  basic  fragility  and  improving  state  capacity  to  promote  social  and  economic 
integration.  Improving  development  effectiveness  in  context-sensitive  situations  requires  a 
detailed understanding of the sources of conflict and fragility and a differentiated approach, with

and strengthening institutions have had mixed success, while standard ADB business processes 
limit project designers’ ability to adapt project design and implementation approaches to the needs 
of FCAS DMCs. To help DMCs overcome challenges presented by context-sensitive situations, 
ADB provides continuous engagement through long-term commitment of resources and capacity 
building. 
 
11.  In an effort to support Strategy 2030, an FCAS team was established in August 2019 in 
SDCC to serve as the corporate focal.13 Going forward, the TA will support government officials 
and development practitioners to facilitate and manage the implementation of context-sensitive 
initiatives and sustainable actions. The TA will also complement existing initiatives to address 
fragile situations in Pacific SIDS,14 similar TA projects in Afghanistan15 and Myanmar,16 and other 
relevant TA projects in operations departments and SDCC.17 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: resilience of DMCs affected by FCAS 
improved (ADB Strategy 2030) (footnote 1). The TA will have the following outcome: performance 
of DMCs integrating context-sensitive approach improved.18 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
13.  Output 1: Strategic approach to context-sensitive situations developed. To better 
support DMC governments to address challenges brought about by contextual sensitivities 
including fragility and/or conflict, the TA will help review and expand the 2013 FCAS Operational 
Plan (footnote 4) into a broader context-sensitive approach. The approach will be aligned with 
ADB’s Strategy 2030 and will reflect international and region-specific best practices. The review 
will  be  based  on:  (i)  the  Pacific  Department’s  assessment  of  its  Pacific  Approach,  2016–
2020 19and internal review of the FCAS Operational Plan to identify which actions have been 
successfully  implemented  and  which  need  further  attention;  and  (ii)  context-sensitive 
development issues identified through a process of consultations with DMCs. To enable DMCs to 
perform better, the review will also look at strategic and operational aspects of DMCs’ and ADB’s  
approaches, including their responses to coronavirus disease 2019, and will identify policies, 
processes, and procedures (e.g., partnership strategies, project design processes, financial 
management, procurement and safeguard requirements) that may need to be revised to facilitate 
improved operations and more sustainable and resilient results in context-sensitive situations. 
Recognizing that border areas are often flash points for fragility and conflict, the TA will support

processes and approaches to facilitate and boost regional cooperation and integration. The 
approach will include crosscutting issues such as gender inequality, expanding civil society 
engagement,  and  youth  inclusion;  and  will  endeavor  to  create  a  platform  to  improve  the 
coordination of ADB support for context-sensitive situations. The approach will also support 
Sustainable Development Goals 16 (promote just, peaceful, and inclusive societies) and 17 
(revitalize the global partnership for sustainable development),and highlight the crosscutting 
issues with the ADB’s seven operational plans, including the private sector.20 The TA will engage 
DMCs through policy dialogue and broad consultations in updating the approach to fit local 
situations. The context-sensitive approach, which will be compiled in a strategic approach paper 
to FCAS, will include performance indicators to track and monitor progress in implementing the 
strategic approach and will provide the overall strategy for addressing contextual issues in the 
entire Asia and Pacific region.  
 
14.  Output 2: Context-sensitive differentiated approaches incorporated in programs 
and projects. The TA will support selected DMCs with context-sensitive situations to design and 
implement projects and programs that best respond to local situations. The TA will provide expert 
guidance and upstream advisory support services to country teams for the formulation of country 
partnership strategies, project pipeline development, and new project designs. The TA will provide 
at least five DMCs with, among others, expertise in governance, public sector and financial 
management, procurement, anticorruption, gender, climate change, and capacity and institutional 
development across sectors and themes (e.g., energy, health, transport, urban development, 
water, and environment). The TA will support the preparation of fragility and conflict assessments, 
including stakeholder analyses, and will employ participatory development processes as they 
apply to context-sensitive situations. In addition, recognizing that effective response in context-
sensitive situations depends on the availability of timely information about local conditions, the TA 
team will prepare situation analyses and briefs for selected DMCs to monitor potential adverse 
situations. These briefs will be updated regularly to ensure that they remain relevant.  
15.  Output 3: Context-sensitive innovative knowledge-based products and services 
created and disseminated.  The TA team will carry out an initial scoping of the knowledge base 
on context-sensitive approaches in at least 10 DMCs. This will help gain a deeper understanding 
of issues and identify successful approaches and tools, including those used by regional and 
global development partners such as the World Bank, that can be continued and/or replicated 
when engaging in context-sensitive situations. Knowledge gaps gleaned from the scoping activity 
will be addressed with the intent of developing innovative knowledge-based solutions tailored to 
local  conditions.  An  online  resource  center,  accessible  to  DMCs,  development  partners, 
nongovernment organizations, and others, will serve as a hub for knowledge dissemination and 
sharing. The TA will support the development of a monitoring tool for context-sensitive situations 
in Asia and the Pacific. The TA will also undertake training needs analyses for line ministries in 
selected DMCs to scope and design capacity-building activities for government officials and 
development practitioners. Inclusive training will support government officials and counterparts to 
gain capacity and unveil solutions to strengthening institutions, catalyzing change, and piloting 
innovative approaches in learning and knowledge sharing. The TA team will develop training and 
awareness materials and carry out integrated workshops and seminars for single DMCs and for 
targeted groups. The TA team will organize a regional event to address context-sensitive issues 
in Asia and the Pacific and enable countries to share knowledge and best practices with a special 
attention to gender inequalities and exclusions.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $3,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6: $2,650,000 and TASF-other sources: $350,000). 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will serve as the executing and implementing agency for the TA. The FCAS team 
under SDCC will undertake the overall administration and implementation of the TA. The FCAS 
team will work and coordinate with operations departments, resident missions, and FCAS focal 
persons to seek concurrence from selected DMCs for country-level activities. SDCC management 
and the FCAS working group21 will review the TA annual program and its progress every 6 months. 
To consider the complexities and risks inherent in working in context-sensitive situations, the TA 
implementation period will be 36 months, from June 2020 to May 2023.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $3,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Enhancing Differentiated Approaches in Context-Sensitive Situations, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.
